_meta.instructions: Merge rules: overwrite description/cues/video_url only if null/empty. Apply prescription_defaults fixes ALWAYS (overwrite).

fixes._comment: BUG: intensity_level was 'medium' but ARC by definition is low (Lattice: 2/10 RPE). Identical prescription to arc_training — differentiation is equipment (requires gym_boulder/spraywall/board).
BUG: prescription was 6x120s/60s — identical to threshold_climbing. Notes say 'Lattice 5x3 style' but actual Lattice Continuity protocol is 5 min on / 3 min off. Fixed to match literature.

prescription_defaults.notes: Grade VERY far below onsight (Lattice: 4-6 letter grades). 5 min climbing / 3 min rest. Must feel conversational — if any pump builds you are too hard. Lattice Continuity 5x3 protocol.

fixes._comment: BUG: work_seconds null — no duration anchor for route laps. 600s (10 min) is a conservative single lap estimate. Prescription remains flexible but adds a time anchor.

prescription_defaults.notes: Easy route laps, ~10 min per lap. Focus recovery, blood flow, movement quality. Grade at least 3 below onsight.

updates.description: ARC (Aerobic Restoration and Capillarization) at easy grade on bouldering wall, spray wall or board. Builds capillary density and forearm aerobic capacity through sustained low-intensity climbing. The defining constraint of ARC is zero pump — any forearm fatigue means the grade is too high. (Lattice: 2/10 RPE for 10-30+ min continuous)
cues: Zero pump is the goal — if forearm starts to fill, step off and rest or switch to easier holds
Hands near heart level to optimize blood flow and reduce cardiovascular strain
Grade 4-5 below boulder onsight — should feel embarrassingly easy
Move continuously: traverses, up-downs, linking easy problems. Stop = failed set
Breathing stays conversational throughout — you should be able to talk normally

updates.description: Classic ARC (Aerobic Restoration and Capillarization) on roped wall or bouldering. 20 minutes of genuinely continuous easy movement at 2/10 RPE. Primary adaptation target is capillary density and forearm aerobic enzyme activity — the foundation of route climbing endurance. Distinguished from gym_arc_easy_volume by longer set duration and route-style movement. (Lattice, Hörst, Gresham — universal aerobic base protocol)
cues: Find the grade where you feel nothing in your forearms — this is your ARC grade today
20 continuous minutes: no rests, no shaking out, no sitting on holds
If pump builds at any point, immediately downclimb or traverse to easier terrain
Eyes and mind can wander — ARC should be so easy it is almost boring
After the set, hold arms above heart for 10-15s then shake out to clear blood

updates.description: Progressive ARC protocol building from 15 min continuous to 30+ min over successive weeks. Ideal first endurance cycle for boulderers transitioning to route training, or returning from injury. Each week add 2-3 minutes per set until 30 min is comfortable. Grade stays fixed — only volume increases. (Lattice progressive load model; Hörst aerobic base programming)
cues: Week 1: 15 min each set. Week 2: 18 min. Week 3: 21 min. Week 4+: continue adding 2-3 min
Grade must stay fixed throughout the progression cycle — never raise grade while building volume
Stop the progression if any pump appears during a set — that signals the grade is creeping up
Keep a timer visible: knowing the remaining time helps pace the effort mentally
300s rest between sets is a minimum — take more if needed to fully recover

updates.description: Sustained sub-onsight climbing on routes at moderate pump. Works the aerobic/anaerobic threshold — the highest intensity maintainable aerobically. Lead route setting at 1 grade below onsight level. Moderate pump acceptable and expected; deep forearm failure is too hard. 2:1 work:rest ratio for route climbing. (Hörst threshold endurance; Gresham training bible 2:1 intervals)
cues: Grade: 1 letter grade below your lead onsight — should feel hard but manageable
RPE 7-8/10 on the wall. Moderate pump is acceptable; cannot-hold-on pump = too hard
120s per set: not a route lap, it's a timed effort. If route ends before 120s, downclimb
60s rest: arms down, shake out actively, breathe. Not a full recovery — that is intentional
6 sets total. Sets 5-6 will feel harder — that metabolic accumulation is the training stimulus

updates.description: Lattice Continuity protocol: 5 min climbing / 3 min rest. Grade is very far below onsight — the defining feature of continuity versus threshold is the absence of any pump. The 5-minute round targets aerobic base without crossing into anaerobic territory. Boulderers can do this on a spray wall or bouldering wall at a very easy grade. (Lattice Training Continuity 5×3 protocol; Tom Randall)
cues: Grade must be 4-6 letter grades below onsight — literally no effort should register in the forearms
5 minutes continuous, zero rest mid-set. If you need to rest, the grade is too hard
3 min rest: enough to fully clear metabolic products before the next set
Boulderers: use the spray wall or traverse at a grade where top moves feel like warm-up
After 4-6 weeks of continuity, transition to ARC for longer continuous sets

updates.description: Repeated laps on easy gym routes for active recovery and blood flow. Grade is 3+ below onsight. Not an endurance training stimulus — it is a recovery activity that maintains movement quality and promotes aerobic restoration between hard sessions. Can substitute for a rest day when the athlete needs movement without load. (Hörst regeneration climbing; Gresham active recovery)
cues: Grade 3+ below onsight — this should require virtually no effort
Focus on technique: silent feet, straight arms, deliberate hip positioning
If forearms are sore from previous days, stop at any onset of worsening
Conversational pace: ideal session to climb and talk with a partner simultaneously
~10 min per lap. 2 min rest between laps. Total 4 laps = ~50 min gentle movement

updates.description: ARC traversing: continuous horizontal movement at very easy grade. Traverses reduce the gravitational component of climbing and allow very long uninterrupted efforts without height anxiety. Ideal for early ARC blocks when 20-min continuous vertical feels psychologically demanding, or when the gym is busy. Same physiological target as arc_training with different movement pattern. (Gresham training bible; Neil Gresham low-intensity endurance guide)
cues: Traverse left-right-left continuously for the full 15-20 min without stepping off
Use any holds — grade is irrelevant on traverses, effort level is what matters
Zero pump is the goal — if forearms start to build, slow down or switch to larger holds
Mix movement patterns: cross-through, step-through, flagging. Use traverse as technique time
Hands near heart level on vertical sections — on slab traverses this is automatic

updates.description: Full redpoint attempts on project-level routes. High-intensity output with full rest between attempts. The primary training goal is project-specific skill acquisition: reading crux sequences, managing pump tactically, and ingraining beta under fatigue. Distinct from training exercises — this is performance-oriented climbing. Record every attempt: holds used, sections recovered, failure point. (Hörst redpoint taper protocol; standard competition prep)
cues: Full rest between attempts: minimum 5-10 min, up to 20 min for hard projects
Two quality attempts are worth more than four fatigued attempts — stop if form degrades
After a fall, immediately identify the failure: technique, fitness, or mental? Log it
Rehearse the crux section individually during rest if execution was messy
Plan attempts around peak freshness: first or second attempt of the session is usually best

updates.description: Threshold intervals performed on bouldering wall, spray wall, or board (not limited to routes). Identical timing to threshold_climbing (120s work / 60s rest) but equipment-agnostic — links boulder problems to accumulate pump rather than climbing a single route. Useful when route gym access is unavailable or when working a specific movement pattern. (Hörst 2:1 threshold intervals; Unlevel Edge 7-min variant reference)
cues: Link 3-5 boulder problems continuously for the 120s round — don't stop between problems
Grade of linked problems: 1-2 below boulder onsight individually, but pump accumulates over 120s
RPE 7-8/10 at the end of each set. First 60s easy, last 60s hard — that progression is correct
60s rest: walk, shake out, breathe deeply. Partial recovery is intentional
Same set count and rest structure as threshold_climbing — sessions are interchangeable in programming

updates.description: 20-30 minutes of continuous climbing at grade 4-6 below onsight. Conversational pace throughout. Used as a cooldown exercise at the end of hard sessions, or as a standalone active recovery session 24-36h after maximum effort days. The forearm aerobic system benefits even at very low intensity — there is no minimum threshold to get an aerobic adaptation stimulus. (Hörst submaximal volume; Lattice regeneration protocol)
cues: Grade 4-6 below your lead onsight — you should be able to close your eyes on the holds
Conversational pace: the acid test is whether you can hold a full conversation while climbing
Arms feel light after 10 min: this is blood flow working. The forearms should never build pump
After a hard session: use this to flush lactate and restore forearm blood flow before leaving the gym
Duration flexible: 20 min minimum, but 30+ min gives a stronger aerobic stimulus

new_exercises.name: Hangboard Moving Hangs (HMH)

prescription_defaults.notes: 5 min moving / 5 min rest. Feet on floor or box behind hangboard. Move hands continuously between holds. Load controlled by hold size and wall angle. Beginner-friendly — safe for intermediate and below.

new_exercises.description: Hörst Hangboard Moving Hangs (HMH): feet supported, hands move continuously between holds. Genuinely different from all static/intermittent protocols — 50/50 duty cycle, active movement, load controlled by hold size and foot position. Trains aerobic forearm endurance when below Critical Force, strength-endurance when above. Ideal entry protocol for climbers new to hangboarding: safe, versatile, and home-compatible. (Hörst, Conditioning for Climbers 2008; StrengthClimbing HMH analysis)
cues: Feet on floor or on a box placed 30-60 cm behind the hangboard — this is load control
Move hands between holds every 5-10 seconds: use different grip positions each set
For aerobic endurance: choose a hold where you feel nothing in the forearms after 3 min
For strength-endurance: choose a hold where mild pump builds by 3-4 min
After dismounting: hold arms above heart level for 10s, then shake out slowly
